div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
ENGLAND AND GERMANY
MR. LEES BELLICOSE SPEECH
SENSATION IN GERMANY
div.p: London, February G. Mr. Lees speech, mentioned in yesterdays telegram, has caused a sensation in Germany. The papers are angrily demanding an explanation. Some of them declare that Germany will now Work with redoubled energy in order to increase her sea power.

Mr. Lees now writes that he was incorrectly reported, and that what he said was that we must assume all naval powers to be possible enemies. Owing to the growth of. such naval powers, our possible enemies are more numerous than hitherto, and, consequently, we have to keep an anxious eye not only on the Medi- terranean but also on the North Sea. The "Standard" learns from Berlin that, unless Lord Lansdowne promptly repudiates the speech, Germany will ask for an explanation

div.head: SITUATION IN RUSSIA.
div.p: Lodz, February 0. Two persons were killed aud 15 wounded at the cemetery here yesterday in a conflict with the troops during the funeral of some of the previous victims. (Reuter).
St. Petersburg, February 6. The address of the nobles asks the Tsar to allow the elected of the nation to participate in the discussion of the measures taken by the Government (Havas).

div.head: GEN. GRIPENBERG'S RESIGNATION.
div.p: St. Petersburg, February 6. General Kuropatsnik reports some skirmishes.

St. Petersburg, February 6. With referonce to the rumours relating to certain that the question was considered some days ago but may that it was then solved by the acceptance of General Gripenberg's resignation

div.head: NORTH SEA COMMISSION.
A COMMISSIONER'S VIEWS
div.p: One of the foreign admirals on the commision of Enquiry, in an intervie with the correspondent said that, while the commisioners are at present convinced of the Russians good faith with reference to the presence of the torpedo boats, the commisioners are unable to believe there were any such boats. The admiral expected that the decision would be such as to enable the russians to walk out with their heads erect. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN LOAN IN FRANCE
div.p: Paris, February 6. Negotiations have been completed for the issue of a 5% Russian loan here. Nearly a millitard of france has been entrusted to the same firms which negotiated the previous Russian loans in france. It is understood the whole loan has been placed. The rate of issue is not stated. (Reuter.)

div.head: OUTRAGE IN FINLAND
div.p: Helsingfors, February 6. A man disguised as an officer, has assasinated Mr. Johnson, Procurator of the senate, and wounded his son. Mr. Johnson, was a Finn, but intensely unpopular as a pronounced pro-russian. His assailant has been arrested. (Reuter.)

div.head: GERMANY AND BULGARIA.
div.p: Sofia, February 6. Prince Ferdinand is to officially visit the Emperor William. (Havas).

div.head: COLLIERS STRIKE IN BELGIUM.
div.p: Brussels, February 6. A general strike of the colliers, in sympathy with the German workmen, began in Belgium today. Ouly 12 pits are now working. (R.)
Charleria, February 6. A strike has broken out in the mining basin. (Havas.)

div.head: FRENCH MILITARY SERVICE
div.p: Paris, February 6. The senate has passed the clause fixing the period of military service at two years. (H.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: A Foundling.—An infant was found by the police yesterday in a street in the Kom-el- Shougats quarter. The Pilgrimage.—A telegram from Jeddah, dated last Saturday, states that the number of pilgrims who have landed there to date amounts to 46,000. Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Ramleh and Moharrem Bey districts on the night of Saturday will be poisoned by the police.

Gruesome Discovery.—The body of a native woman, with the head, hauds, and legs cut out, was found yesterday on the banks of the Mah- moudieh Canal, near Ramleh, and removed to the Government Hospital.

Bank of Egypt.—In regard to the recently declared 10% dividend of the Bank of Egypt, we may mention that this and a bonus of 15s. per share is equal to a net distribution to the shareholders of 16% of the bank's capital for one year.

The Mahmal Theft.—It is suggested that, in future, to avoid theft of bullion and valu- able, such as occurred in the recent case of the mahmal, the Railway Administration should construct special cars fitted up as strong-rooms for the transport of treasure.

Ploughing Competition. — the Khedivia. Agricultural Society has decided to hold some official trials of a number of steam-ploughiug machines at shoubra on tue 24th inst. About six different machines have already been entered for the Competition.

Suez Canal.—34 vessels passed through the Canal on the 2nd and 3rd inst. 23 of which were british, 2 Norwegian, 4 French, 2 Aus- trian, 1 Turkish, 1 Swedish, 1 Dutch, 1 Ger- man, the receipts for the two days being irs. 884.684.06. The total for the 3 days in February amounted to frs. 1,129,100.51.

Delta Light Railway Co.—The Committee of the London Stock Exchange has ordered the following securiiy to be quoted in the official List: Egyptian Delta Light Railways, further issue of 11,113 5g per cent. Cumulative pre- reference Shares of 10 each, fully paid, Nos. 63,325 to 74,437 (registerd shares and share warrants to bearer).

Menahouse Gymkhana— the total number of visitors on Friday who passed through the gates at the Menahouse Gymkhana was 800, which is a record “gain.". No less than 53o luncheons were served on that day in the big dining-hall at Mena House Hotel, The arrangements were througuout excellent.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive has returned to Koubbeh. His highness will come to Alexandria on Thursday next

div.head: PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
div.p: The public works department has fixed the following salaries for the under-mentioned officials. The figures given represent pounds egyptian:- Technical Service :— C. Crawley, 700; J. Lamella Bey, 450. Towns and State Buildings.—Clifton, 1,000 ; Hewat, 1,000; Rebeot, 700 ; Chapman, 600; Pastour, 600 ; Ehrlich, 600; Euser, 400 ; Wat- son, 400 ; Zoucas, 831 ; H. Passe, 360 ; Srnir- giassi, 300 ; Bertrand, 276; M. H. FitzPatriok, 276. Irrigation Service.—H. G. Piulaison 800 ; Mahmoud Bey Sidky, 900; Mofeaworth, 700 ; Adamson, 600 ; B xwell, 600 ; Lamb ton, 430 ; C-raper, 480 ; Sullivan, 300. Survey Department—Captain Lyons, 1,400, H. Hmuplireys, 720 ; Robert Bey 540 ; L. Craig, 076 ; A. Lucas, 540, G. Fraser, B. Wade and Dowson, 480 ; H. Skill, 360 ; B. Weldon, 300; E Binosi, 240 ; Bertrano, 276 ; Elias Bey Sabbagh, 420. Antiquity Service.—E Brugsch Bey, 800 ; J. Quibeli and H. Carter, 600 ; G. Daressy, 500G. Leg rain, 480.

div.head: BECK AND CO'S PILSENER BEER
div.p: Fears no honest competition for quality.

div.head: LORD CROMER’S TRIP.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.) Medinet el-Fayoum, Sunday. Lord Cromer's speech here yesterday has made a very good impression, and his strongly- worded criticism on the growth of drinking habits has been taken to heart. Many of the omdehs who were among Lord Cromer’s au- dience, were so impressed that they have told me that they intend to petition the Govern- ment against the manner in which liquor shops are being opened everywhere in the villages without let or hindance. I intend to found a local society hero to combat the alcohofic habit among the natives. Lord and Lady Cromer and Lady Betrice Thynne paid a visit to one of the native kuttabs hero which is under the care of the Ministry of Public Instruction They also visited the native Sefa Coulop rohoof. Della Bey, French consular agent here, and the members of the schoof committee recieved his lordship there. the party took tea at the Moudir’s residence and left at 3.15 pm for Wests.
Lord and lady Cromer are expected to arrive at Beni Hasan this evening. We hear that Lord Cromer Is busily engaged on his annual report,

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: During the week ending saturday only two cases of plague were reported throughout Egypt, one at suez and the other in the Toukh district.

div.head: BOVINE TYPHUS
div.p: During last week, 11 deaths from bovine typus were reported throughout Egypt, as against 6,164 deaths during the corresponding week last year. The total number of deaths to date amounts to 146,803

div.head: A CASE FOR ENQUIRY.
div.p: A cairo correspondent writes:- to the west of Abdeen-square is a nasty quarter where few sanitary and moral laws are enforced and where the grossest criminality prevails. While in that locality today I learned that in a quarrel between an armenian and three natives the armenian was so badly beaten that he, after a week or more, died, and nothing has been done to assailate or murderers. In fact, the principal was pointed out to me, and i was informed that a seargant of police was bribed to strike this mans name off the book for they all were arrested at the time of the quarrel. I wish this matter to be inquired into, for it is a most gross outrage if it is true as i am led to believe it is.

div.head: PROF FELIX'S RECITAL
div.p: Professor Felix's concert took place at the Khedivial Hotel on Saturday night as an- nounced, and considering the wet and tem- pestous weather, was well attended. We must congratulate the professor on his courage in fixing a more modest price for the tickets than is customary here for local artists, who ex- pect their kind friends to pay the same price for the pleasure of bearing them perform as they would do for distinguished artistes from Europe who can command audiences without the disagreeable touting system in vogue in this country. Mr. Felix's selection of piece was as it ought to have been, a happy one, as his silvery touch was shown off to perfection in most of them. If there was one piece more than another that elicited enthusiastic applause we might pick out an exquisite Nocturne of Chopin's (Opus 15 No. 2), in which an oft-recurring melody framed in flow mg cadenzas brought ont the pianist's remark able agility of finger. Wagner’s "Choeur des Fileuses” from his "Vaissean Fantome” arranged by Lizt, was also much appreciated. Mr. Felix's wonderfully delicate touch is not so well suited to the heavier German music, which requires greater breadth of tone and a deeper sentiment. To our mind his conception of Mendelssohn’s "Fruhlings Lied” was quite incorrect and far removed from the traditional one as taught in German Conaervatories,but on the other hand, the Duo by the same com- poser was faultlessly played. Professor Felix was ably supported by Mrs. Frederick Cree, who sang, first, a romance by Giordano from Andrea Chenier with great refinement, and in the socond part Beetho- ven's famous “Per Pieta.” Her passionate rendering of the presto, “Ah crudel I” quite carried away her audience, and on being encored she repeated it with even more verve than the first time. We must not omit the lovely little duet by Missa, “Les Roseaux Chanteurs," charmingly suug by Mrs. Cree and Mme. Felix, nor the instrumental trio performed very ably by Mr. H. and Mr. L. Suzan accom panied by Mr. Felix. Altogether a very plea- sant concert, but we must suggest that another time the pauses between the items should be curtailed, and that a performer does not ussually retire from the platform between two pieces bracketed a and b. All praise to Mr. Lifonti for the splendid Pleyel pianoforte lent for the oocasion.

BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE- we would call the attention of persons interested in Egyptian trade to the work of the british chamber of commerce of egypt, whose office in alexandria gives information as to standings, trade, and to its members , and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce The annual subscription is $1 and all british traders should become members. Our London office, 86, New Broad street E.C. acts as Londond agency to the Chamber

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN
H. M. S. Sealark Damaged.
div.p: (From our Correspondent). Suakin, January 28. H. M. S. '‘Sealark’’ arrived here from Sheikh Barghont on the 14th inst in a damaged ion- dition, having struck a rock about 4 miles off Sheikh Barghout whilst surveying. She had to come into Suakin for the necessery repairs, which have now been carried, out with the aid of divers and material obtained from the Sudan Government Railways The "Sealark" after surveying here and at Sheikh Barghout, will probably go into dock and then continue her survey as far as Australia, which is her final destination. The British S.S. "Dart” arrived from Eng- land on the 14th inst. with a very largo con- signment of rails and fishplates for the Suakin- Atbara Railways The British S.S. "Thornley” arrived from England on the 16th inst, with a large consign- ment of iron sleepers for the railway.

div.head: THE POWELL COTTON EXPEDITION
div.p: According to intelligence just to hand, major Powell-Cotton, who left Khartoum on an expedition from the Nile to the Zambesi, was at Lado at the end of December. The expedition was making good progress and was meeting with every assistance from the officials. The explorer was in good health.

div.head: EGYPTIAN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY.
div.p: Some foolish complaints have appeared in some of the Cairo newspapers in regard to the allotment of the shares of the Egyptian Investment Agency, Limited. This outcry is absolute nonsense, for the company has no concession nor patents, and any one of the persons who consider themselves aggrieved in not having been allotted shares, can start as many companies for general financial business as they like on exactly similar conditions

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: The chambers of Mr. J Nortin Kushe, Barrister at law, are situated at Maison Spiro, first floor, opposite the savoy hotel, Kaar-el-nil, Cairo.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE
div.p: The Khedlvial Opera House reasserted itself in La Totea. The performance was in every way excellent. Signora Pandolfini obtain- ed and justified the welcome due to an old Cairo favorite both by her singing and by her acting. Signor Girand was pleasing and artistic, and Signor Polese was conspicuous for the excellence of his acting; we could wish: that all opera singers would give as much attention to details. "II Sagrestano" was amusing ; and we should like to hear more of Sig- nor Sala, the “timbre" of whose voice has some charm. Staging and choris were alike all that could be desired. We trust that other performances will maintain this level, and do away with the undoubtedly bad impression caused by Rigoletto (amongst Other pieces given). We would say one word as to the orchestra. Though, it is certainly composed of good musicians and directed by an efficient oonductor, there is often apparent a certain want of judgment, which might well be remedied, a lack of complete harmony with the singers, This, in light opera, where the melodies for the chief performers are the most prominent part, may not be so harmful in effect: but it is fatal in any such opera as Tristan, or indeed in any piece where the composer has devoted his attention to the music and not only to these who execute it In a word, we would wish to find (and we-have a right to expect) that sense of ensemble which it is the duty, as it should be the pleasure, of the Khedlvial Opera Honse to

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE
LUCIA DI LAMMERMOOR
div.p: Signora Isabella Sricher, the celebrated operatic artiste, who created such a furore at the Verdi Theatre in Cairo, and whose advent bad been anxiously awaited by a large section of the music-loving public, made her debut at the Abbas helmy Theatre on Satdrday Even- ing in Lucia di Lammermoor, and her magni- ficent performance reached to the full the highest expectations which had been formed regarding her. To say that Signora Svicher was admirable or excellent, would be but to very mildly express the quality of her per formapoe, from every point of view. Indeed, we venture to say that never has Egypt before been honored by the presence of two such magnificent artistes as Signs. Gemma Bellin- cioni and Sigus. Isabella Sricher, and from the rapturous applause so lavishly bestowed by enthusiastic and delighted audiences on each of these accomplished ladies, it is oertain that the season will be a successful one. Signa. Svicher's Lucia, on Saturday, was an inter- pretation such as is seldom seen. Her singing was certainly a revelation to many present, and herr acting was of a high order and showed careful study of this mobt difficult rfllo. The tenor, Signor Tomiaaui being unwell, the role of Sir Edgard was sustained by Signor Pagani, who scored a distinct success. In fact, we think we have never heard Signor Pagani to better advantage. Signor Baldelli, in the small part of Raimondo, was excellent. The other minor parts were in good hands and the orchestra and chorus were fully up to their usual standard.

div.head: ANDREA CHENIER.
div.p: An admirable performance of Giordano’s Andrea Chenier was given on Sunday night. Signor Pagani was in splendid voice and gave an excellent interpretation of the exceedingly trying title role. He was the success of the evening. Signora D. Bassich, who made her debut on this oocasion, gave a fairly good rendering of the part of Maddalens di.'Coigny, but her voice is not robust enough to stand her in good steed in an opera like Andrea Chenier. As Carlo Gerard, the baritone Badini, who possesses a voice of delightful freshness, was eminently successful. Sig. Montanari also scored a distinct success.

div.head: RIGOLETTO
div.p: Last night, a very excellent performance of Rigoletto was given at the Abhas Theatre. Excellent, we say, because in every respect the “ensemble” was a matter for admiration and, at times, even for Surprise. In Rigoletto Verdi began to realise in a way which he hitherto had not surmised, the important and extensive powers of his mind Up to this point he had written many tunes which had been hummed and sung throughout the whole world, but here he seemed to forego the enormous spirit of tune that was within him, and to give himself up entirely to the dramatic matter in hand. Last night's per formance of the opera was eminently successful. Signora Svicher, in the part of Gilda, was from every point of view a very great success ; her voice, which possesses some of the most exquisite qualities of modern vocalisation, was proved on this oocasion to possess an exquisite and, if one may use the adjective in connection with singing, a shining quality that impressed one enormously, by reason of the absolute purity of its evocation. Her range is enormous; she never misses her effects, and, to sum up, we regard her in no other light than that she is dazzlingly brilliant She was frantically applauded, especially after her delightful rendering of “Caro noms,” which she was obliged to repeat Sig. Tomisani took the part of the Duke and enchanted everybody by the magnificence of his singing. He is a tenor of great power, and was in good form last night, enthusiasm on the part of the audience following everything he did. It stands to reason therefore that his rendering of "La Donna e mobile” waa triumphantly successful. In the part of Rigoletto Signor Badini sang excellently, though he did not impress us very much with his acting. The other parts were in good hands. The chorus was at times disappointing, but on the whole good, while the orchestra deserves credit. Tomorrow night, Signore Ballincioni will appear in Fedora

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The "Sehleswig" arrived at Alexandria at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon and most of the passengers, 92 first class and 52 second class, left by a special train for Cairo. Prince Lichtenstein, Count and countess von Arnim, Baron and Baroness de Serclaes, Count von Trautmansdorff, Count d'Ursel, and a number of other distinguished tourists arrived by this steamer. The complete list of passengers will be publsihed tomorrow. The "Schleswig" leaves Alexandria on wednesday afternoon at 5 o'clock as usual. A number of passengers have already been booked.
Conolel Sir Adolphus FitsGeorge, the third son of the late Duke of Cambridge, whose private secretary and equerry he was for many years, has arrived in Egypt from Marseilles
Sir John and lady Evans will leave for Khartoum next week
Miralai C.E. Wilson Bey has been appointed Commanant of Senasr military district

Liutenant-colonel Kenns, V.C., D.S.O. who was such a popular figure in Cairo society when the 21st Lancers were here, is to be married in London early next month to Angela Mary, youngest daughter of the late Hubers Hibbert and Mrs. Hubert Hibbert, of 2, beaufort-gardens.

The 2nd class of the order of the medjidieh has been conferred by the Khedive on Mr. Law, Judge of the mixed trubunals at Cairo, on the occasion of his retirement. His Highness will give audience to Judge Law on the 13th isnt.
Mr. A.H. Perry has gone to Port Said, and will return to Cairo on Wednesday
The great italian actor, Sig. Novelli, will arrive at alexandria from italy early next month

We regret to announce the death of well known Egyptian resident at Stamboul in the person of Mehmed Bey, member of the finan- cial section of the Council of State, who died on the morning of the 24th ulto. at his residence at Beshiktash. The funeral took place in the afterooon at the expense of the Privy Purse. The late Bey was the son of Ibrahim Pasha, and grand-nephew of Mohamed Aly Pasha.

Among others to be seen dining in Shepheard's Restaurant, yesterday evening, we noticed Prince Lichtenstein, Baron von Drasch and a party, including Mr. and Mrs. Beckham, Mr. Baines and a party of 8, Marquis de Corea, Barou de Walzdorf and friends, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Nixon and a party of 10, including Mrs. Mather, Mr. Morton, Mr. and Mrs. John dupec; Baron de Wecker, M. Ernpaiu and some Friends, Vicomte and Vicomtease de Fontarce, Vicomte de Sapucahy, Mr. and Mrs. O'Donnell Hiller, Liuut. and Mrs. von Meyer and a few friends, Mr, Mrs., and the Mieees Runerty, Mr. E. de Szeut-Ivauy and.friends Mr. P. de la Bella Casa and a party, etc.

The small dance at Shepheard's last night, it is needless to say, was a great success. Among the dancers we remarked. Mrs and miss carhardt, the misses bufferty, miss wildbur, miss H. Porter, the Misses budhead, Mrs. and the Misses haisen, the misses de gelshemen, the misses hillen, baron and baroness de vassilko, baron M. Oppenheim, baron Dobrenski, Chebalier de rappard, Herr von pohl, Mr. and Mrs Calame, Etc.
Mr. Givson Bowles, M.P., and Sir Curson and lady Wyllie are among the latest arrivals at the cataract hotel, assouan.

Other arrivals at the popular up river hotel include: mr and mrs e willis swan, mr and mrs r lenk, mrs h meyer, mr. j. lamont, mr c mohr, mr r l and miss gardiner messrs. Jungfleish, messrs cohen, mr. j. tremaune, mr john l low, mr c s friedrichs, mr and mrs e r ackerman, mr mrs sud the misses pinkerton, mr max heuraux, mr and miss l braithwaite, mr fuller maitland, miss maitland, mrs webster, missee atrindale, mrs saunders, capt jackson, misses miles, miss waterhouse col watson, mr jules aghion, mr. g chaix dest ange, count b, tyazkiewics, mrs standish , mr and mrs hugh cooper, mr otway tolar, mr ch. r. mcvicar, mrs and miss henry lee.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, LUXOR,
div.p: Best and most comfortable, unique for its position on Nile bank. Under Garmon Manage ment. Moderate charges. Patronised by officer of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable hotel in alexandria, facing the sea central position. Under english management

div.head: Anglo-American Nile Steamer and hotel company
div.p: River transport of coods between alexandria and cairo. Three sailings a week. Agents of alexandria: alexandria bonded warehouse co.
